a b s t r a c t
In the present study, three MgO nanomaterials (MgOS, MgON and MgOU) were synthesized by sol–gel and two different precipitation methods, respectively, and used for the sorption of Remazol Red RB-133 from aqueous solution. The effect of parameters like contact time, initial dye concentration and temperature on the adsorption capacity was studied. The adsorption isotherm studies were carried out using Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin models. Langmuir was the most suitable model to describe the adsorption isotherm. Pseudo- first -order model fitted well with good agreement with the experimental values of qe (equilibrium adsorption capacity). The complete removal efficiency of the dye on MgOS, MgON and MgOU adsorbents was attained when the contacting time was continued to 11, 40 and 60 min, respectively. Hence, the MgOS adsorbent was found to possess the highest removal efficiency of the dye from aqueous solutions. In addition, the thermodynamic parameters, DH , DS , DG , and Ea were also calculated for Remazol Red RB-133 adsorption onto MgOS adsorbent. In order to reveal the adsorptive characteristic of MgO nanomaterials, XRD, HR-TEM, FT-IR and N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out. The results showed that MgOS nanomaterial had potentially lowering capital and operational costs for practical applications. 2015 The Society of Powder Technology Japan. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Synthetic dyes are widely used in textile, paper, printing, plastic, leather and cosmetic industries. Dyeing effluent has a serious environmental impact because its disposal into water causes carcinogenic effects. Furthermore, colored effluent can affect photosynthetic processes of aquatic plants, reducing oxygen levels in water and in severe cases, resulting in the suffocation of aquatic flora and fauna [1]. Various pollutants such as dyes, degradable organics, surfactants, heavy metals, and pH adjusting chemicals can be found in textile wastewater [2]. Conventional treatment methods for removal of pollutants from aqueous solution, like photochemical degradation, biological degradation, coagulation, chemical oxidation and adsorption have been investigated with varying degree of success [3–5]. Among available wastewaters
treatment technologies, adsorption is rapidly gaining prominence as a method of treating aqueous effluent. The most widely used adsorbent is activated carbon, but its initial cost and the need for a costly regeneration system make it less economically viable as an adsorbent. This has led many researchers to search for cost effective and efficient alternative materials such as clays including bentonite [6], sepiolite [7], zeolite [8], and periodic mesoporous titanium phosphonate [9]. Recently, nanocrystalline metal oxides have gained considerable interest among researchers as potential adsorbents for decontamination of wastewater [10]. Due to their high surface area, large numbers of highly reactive edges, corner defect sites, unusual lattice planes and high surface to volume ratio.
Magnesiumoxide (MgO) is a versatilemetal oxidehavingnumerousapplications inmanyfields. It hasbeenusedas a catalyst andcatalyst support for various organic reactions [11,12], as an adsorbent for removing dyes and heavy metals from wastewater [13,14], antimicrobial material [15], and electrochemical biosensor [16]. Obtaining MgO via thermal decomposition of various magnesium salts give large crystallite sizewith low surface area-to-volume ratio that limits its applications for nanotechnology especially in adsorp-
inetics,
tion and catalysis [17,18]. Formation of MgO nanostructures with a small crystallite size of less than 100 nm and homogeneous morphology has attracted much attention due to their unique physicochemical properties including high surface area-to-volume ratio. It iswidelyaccepted that thepropertiesofMgOnanostructures depend stronglyon the synthesismethods and theprocessing conditions. MgO nanostructure was synthesized using precipitation [19], solvothermal [20], chemical vapour deposition [21], sonochemical [22], microwave [23], combustion [24] and template [25] methods. Each method has its own advantages and disadvantages. An important issue regarding synthesis and preparation of nanostructured MgO is controlling the parameters in order to obtain amore uniform size as well as morphology of the nanoparticles.
A sol–gel method is a promising technique for the formation of magnesium oxalate di-hydrate followed by annealing at a suitable temperature to form MgO. The advantages are its simplicity, low cost, low reaction temperature, high surface area-to-volume ratio and high purity of the final product. The present study is focused on the effect of preparing MgO nanomaterials by different methods for removal of Remazol Red RB-133 from aqueous solution. The as-prepared adsorbents were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms. The removal studies of the dye byMgOnanomaterials have been carried out using batch adsorption experiments. The influenceof various importantparameters, suchas contact time, initial dye concentration and temperature was investigated. The isotherm studieswere carried out using Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkinmodels. Pseudo-first-order, pseudo-secondorder and intra-particle diffusion kinetic models were used to evaluate themechanismof adsorption. The thermodynamic parameters, such as DG , DH , and DS were calculated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Remazol Red RB-133 (RR RB-133) was purchased from DyStar and was used as received without further purification. The UV–visible absorption spectrum of Remazol Red RB-133 shows characteristic absorption both in UV and visible regions. The concentration of Remazol Red RB-133 was measured at kmax 520 nm throughout the work. Magnesium nitrate, (Mg(NO3)2 6H2O, BDH), oxalic acid dihydrate, (C2H2O4 2H2O, Adwic), urea, [(NH2)2CO, Adwic], absolute ethanol, C2H5OH (Adwic, 99.9% purity) and ammonia solution, (NH4OH, Alpha). Bi-distilled water was used to prepare all the solutions. An accurate weighed quantity of the dye was dissolved in bi-distilled water to prepare a stock and the diluted dye solutions.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Sol–gel method
sections.text: The MgO nanomaterial was prepared by sol–gel method. Initially, Magnesium nitrate and oxalic acid precursors in 1:1 M ratio were first dissolved separately in ethanol and stirred magnetically to obtain two clear solutions, then mixed together to yield a thick white gel. The gel product was digested for 12 h and dried subsequently at 100 C for 24 h and then calcined at 500 C for 3 h. The nominated formula of the prepared adsorbent is MgOS, where S indicates the sol–gel method.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Precipitation method
sections.text:
The MgO nanomaterials were synthesized using two different precipitation methods – one used ammonium hydroxide as the precipitating agent and the other urea.
Please cite this article in press as: H.R. Mahmoud et al., Textile dye removal fro isotherm studies and thermodynamics, Advanced Powder Technology (2015),
For the ammoniaprecipitated adsorbent, 0.2 MNH4OHwas added drop-wise to 200 mL of 1 MMg(NO3)2 6H2O at 50 C till aqueous solution pH reached 10 under vigorous stirring. The so-formed white precipitate was washed several times with bi-distilledwater, dried overnight in anoven at 110 C andfinally calcined at 500 C for 3 h in a muffle furnace to get MgO nanomaterial.
For the urea precipitated adsorbent, urea (40 g) and 200 mL of 1 MMg(NO3)2.6H2O were aged under reflux conditions with stirring in a round-bottomed flask for 4 h at 100 C in the pH reached 10.5. The resulting slurry was filtered, washed with bi-distilled water and dried at 70 C overnight. This was followed by calcination in a muffle furnace at 500 C for 3 h. The nominated formula for the adsorbents is MgON and MgOU, which denotes precipitation using ammonia and urea respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text: PowderX-raydiffraction (XRD) studywas carriedoutusingBruker Axs D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Germany). CuKa1 irradiation (k = 0.15404Å)was usedwith a scan rate of 2 in 2h/min. The crystallite sizeof thesamplewas calculatedusing theScherrer equation [26]. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was recorded on Nicolit IR6700 spectrometer (USA)usingKBrpellets. Themorphology of the adsorbents was analyzed using high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) (JEM-2100CX (JEOL). The textural properties of the samples were determined by physically adsorbing nitrogen (N2) at 77 K using a Quantochrome AS1WinTM-automated gas-sorption apparatus (USA). Before eachN2 sorptionmeasurement, samples were degassed at 200 C for 2 h. The N2 adsorption on the samples was used to calculate the specific surface area by means of the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. The total pore volume, Vp was estimated to be the liquid volume of the nitrogen at a relative pressure of about 0.99. The pore size distributionwas calculated from desorption branch of the isothermby the Barrett, Joyner andHalenda (BJH) method.

sections.heading: 2.4. Adsorption experiments
sections.text:
Batch adsorption study of water-soluble reactive dye Remazol Red RB-133 (RR RB-133) onto MgO nanomaterials was carried out in 250 mL beakers which contained 100 mg MgO and 100 mL dye solution of desired concentration. The solution in the beakers was kept stirred at the desired temperature and pH = 7. At various time intervals, the solutions were centrifuged at 7000 rpm for 5 min and the absorbance of supernatant solution was recorded using UV–vis spectrophotometer (Jasco V-550, Japan). The corresponding concentration in the supernatant solution was obtained using a previously constructed calibration graph. The equilibrium adsorption capacities (qe) were then obtained by using the following mass balance equation.
qe ¼ ðCo CeÞ V=M ð1Þ where Co and Ce are the initial and equilibrium dye concentrations in solution (mg/L), V is the solution volume (L) and M is the weight (g) of dry adsorbent used.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Effect of contact time
sections.text:
The effect of contact time was investigated by taking 100 mL of 75 mg L 1 Remazol Red RB-133 solution (pH 7.0). MgO nanomaterials (100 mg) were added and then the whole solution was stirred at 35 C. An aliquot (3 mL) of dye sample was withdrawn from the beaker at regular time intervals and centrifuged. The concentration of dye in the supernatant solution was analyzed and the percentage removal (%R) of dye is calculated using the following relation:
%Removal ¼ 100 ðCo CtÞ=Co ð2Þ

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
The adsorption isotherm indicates how the adsorbing molecules distribute between the liquid phase and the solid phase when the adsorption process reaches an equilibrium state. Adsorption isotherm experiments were carried out as batch tests by adding a fixed amount (100 mg) of adsorbent to a series of 250 mL glass beakers filled with 100 mL of dye solutions (25–75 mg L 1) at 35 C. Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin isotherms were used to analyze the adsorption equilibrium.
Langmuir isotherm model [27] assumes that the adsorptions occur at specific homogeneous sites on the adsorbent and is used successfully in many monolayer adsorption processes. The linearized form of Langmuir equation is as follows:
Ce=qe ¼ Ce=qmax þ 1=KL qmax ð3Þ
where Ce is the equilibrium concentration of dye in the solution (mg/L), qe is the equilibrium capacity of dye on the adsorbent (mg/g), qmax is the maximum adsorption capacity of the adsorbent corresponding to complete monolayer coverage on the surface (mg/g), and KL is the Langmuir adsorption constant (L/mg) and is related to the free energy of adsorption. The constants qmax and KL can be calculated from the intercept and the slope of the linear plot of Ce/qe versus Ce.
Freundlich isotherm model [28] is applicable for non-ideal sorption on heterogeneous surfaces and multilayer sorption. The linearized form of the equation is as follows:
ln qe ¼ ln KF þ 1=n ln Ce ð4Þ
where KF and 1/n are characteristic constants representing the adsorption capacity and adsorption intensity of the system respec-

tively. The values of KF and 1/n are obtained from the linear plot of lnqe versus ln Ce.
Temkin isotherm model [29] takes into account adsorbate–adsorbent interactions and assumes that fall in the heat of adsorption is linear rather than logarithmic, as implied in Freundlich equation. The linear form of Temkin relationship can be given as follows:
qe ¼ b lnaþ b ln Ce ð5Þ where
b ¼ RT=b ð6Þ T is the absolute temperature in Kelvin, R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J/mol K), and b is the Temkin constant related to heat of adsorption (J mg 1). The Temkin constants a and b are calculated from the slope and intercept of linear plot of qe versus lnCe.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
Kinetics is important for adsorption studies because it can predict the rate at which a pollutant was removed from aqueous solutions and provides valuable data for understanding the mechanism of sorption reactions. The adsorption kinetic experiments were carried out in batch mode by taking 100 mL of 75 mg L 1 dye solution at 35 C. In order to investigate the mechanism of dye sorption onto MgO nanomaterials, pseudo-first-order and pseudo-secondorder models were adopted. The pseudo-first-order rate equation of Lagergren [30] is given by:
ln ðqe qtÞ ¼ ln qe k1 t ð7Þ where qe and qt are the amounts of dye adsorbed (mg/g) at equilibrium and at time t (min) respectively and k1 (min 1) is the pseudo-first-order rate constant. Values of k1 were calculated from the plot of ln (qe qt) versus t.
The rate equation for Ho’s pseudo-second-order model [31,32] is given by:

The kinetic results were also analyzed by intra-particle diffusion model to gain further insight into the adsorption behavior of dyes on MgO nanomaterials. This model is significant to know the rate determining step in the liquid adsorption systems. The rate limiting step may be either the boundary layer (film) or the intra- particle (pore) diffusion of solute on the solid surface from bulk of the solution in a batch process. The probability of the intra-particle diffusion was explored by using the modified Weber and Morris [33] equation:
qt ¼ kdif t0:5 þ C ð9Þ where qt is adsorption capacity at any time t and kdif is the intraparticle diffusion rate constant (mg/g min½) and C is the film thickness. The values of kdif and C were calculated from the slope and intercept of plots of qt versus t0.5. If the rate limiting step be the intra-particle diffusion, the plot of qt against the square root of time should be a straight line and pass through the origin with C = 0. Any deviation from the linearity clearly indicates the rate-limiting step should be boundary layer (film) diffusion controlled [34–36].

sections.heading: 3.1.1. XRD analysis
sections.text: XRD is used for identification of the crystal phase and crystallite size of each phase present. XRD patterns of MgOS, MgON and MgOU nanomaterials calcined at 500 C were shown in Fig. 1a. The diffractograms matched with the face centered cubic structure of periclase MgO (JCPDS No. 78-0430) [37]. The major peaks at 2h values of 37.1 , 43.0 and 62.4 can be indexed to the lattice planes of (111), (200) and (220), respectively. The intense peaks in the XRD of MgOU revealed that the obtained product was more crystalline than MgON and MgOS. The crystallite size was estimated using the Scherrer equation [26]. The order of decreasing the main crystallite size of periclase MgO phase for different nanomaterials was as following: MgOS < MgON < MgOU, which were found to be 12.9, 13.1 and 27.5 nm, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Morphology study
sections.text: To investigate the structural and morphological characteristics of MgO nanomaterials prepared by different methods, the adsorbents (MgOS, MgON and MgOU) have been examined by highresolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), as shown in Fig. 1b. A careful inspection of Fig. 1b showed that the MgOS adsorbent particles are composed of aggregates have cube like shapes with an average diameter of 11.5 nm and nanorod-like shape with average diameter and length of 2.4 and 16.2 nm, respectively. On the other hand, the MgON adsorbent particles were composed of a layered structure. Moreover, the aggregates of layers or sheets forms a flower like structures. However, on inspection of the micrograph MgOU, it can be seen that the particles have cube like and irregular shapes with an average diameter of 24.8 nm. The average particle size calculated from the TEM micrographs was consistent well with the average crystallite size calculated from the XRD studies. From this it was concluded that the preparation method could affect the morphology of the product.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. BET surface area and pore characteristics
sections.text:
The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore-size distribution plot of different MgO nanomaterials was shown in
Please cite this article in press as: H.R. Mahmoud et al., Textile dye removal fro isotherm studies and thermodynamics, Advanced Powder Technology (2015),
Fig. 2(a) and (b), respectively. The isotherms of different MgO nanomaterials could be classified as a typical type II according to the IUPAC classification [38], which was typical of either nonporous or mixed pore system. The order of BET surface areas for the MgO nanomaterials was as follows: MgOS (124.6 m2/g) > MgON (103.8 m2/g) > MgOU (42.1 m2/g). Moreover, the pore volume for MgO nanomaterials was as follows: MgOS (0.30 cm3/g) > MgON (0.13 cm3/g) > MgOU (0.06 cm3/g). These findings revealed that the adsorbent prepared by sol–gel method had the highest surface area and pore volume which were advantageous for dye adsorption. Meanwhile, the urea precipitated adsorbent had the smallest surface area and pore volume. Generally, an adsorbent with large surface area and high pore volume leads to more exposed surface sites for dye adsorption [39]. Therefore, the MgOS is more favorable for enhanced the removal of Remazol Red RB-133 compared to MgOU adsorbent.
The pore size distribution plot of MgO nanomaterials, Fig. 2(b), shows multimodal distributions. The average pore diameter for MgOS, MgON and MgOU was 3.6, 3.5 and 3.1 nm, respectively. They belong to the mesopore region according to IUPAC classification [40]. Finally, we note that the results of the textural characterization are in agreement with the XRD and TEM discussed earlier.

sections.heading: 3.1.4. FT-IR analysis
sections.text: FT-IR spectra of MgOS, MgON and MgOU nanomaterials were shown in Fig. 3. The sharp peak at 3700 cm 1 for all MgO adsorbents corresponds to the free hydroxyl group ( OH) stretching mode [41]. The broad bands observed at high frequencies in the IR spectrum extending from 3400 to 3200 cm 1, are due to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching modes of the hydroxyl group, which reveal the existence of adsorbed water molecules on the MgO surface [42]. The bending modes of the adsorbed water molecules appear as a weak band around 1640 cm 1 [43]. A broad band at 1460–1400 cm 1 corresponds to the Mg O stretching vibrations as well as the Mg O Mg deformation vibrations [44]. The bands belonging to M OH are present near 1100 cm 1 [45]. The stretching vibrations of the Mg O bands were observed around 860 and 680 cm 1 while their bending modes were located at 440 cm 1 [41].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
The plots obtained for Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin isotherm models on different MgO nanomaterials were shown in Fig. 5(a–c), respectively. The parameters calculated for the three isotherm models were summarized in Table 1. Model fitting to these equilibrium adsorption results of the dye were evaluated based on the values of the correlation coefficient (R2) of the linear regression plot. Table 1 shows that Langmuir isotherm gives more satisfactory fitting to the adsorption isotherms of the dye on different MgO adsorbents with correlation efficient (R2) higher than 0.99, indicating a good agreement of the data. Thus it may be concluded that Langmuir model is suitable to describe the adsorption of Remazol Red RB-133 on different MgO nanomaterials, which emphasizes the formation of monolayer coverage of dye molecules at specific homogeneous sites on the adsorbent surface. Furthermore, one can find that the constant KL increase as a following: MgOS > MgON > MgOU. The results revealed that the MgOS nanomaterial had the highest adsorption ability. The reason was attributed to its small particle size and highest surface area and pore volume. It has been reported that the smaller particle size solid enhanced better migration and interaction of the adsorbate to the active adsorbent sites than the longer one [47].
The essential feature of the Langmuir isotherm may be expressed in terms of a dimensionless constant called separation factor (RL) [48] studies on which is given by the following equation.
RL ¼ 1=1þ KLCo ð10Þ The RL values within the range 0 < RL < 1 indicate a favorable adsorption [49,50]. In the present study, RL values obtained were in the range of 0.004–0.006, indicating favorable adsorption of dye on different MgO nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second-order and intra-particle diffusionplots for theadsorptionofRemazolRedRB-133ondifferent MgOnanomaterialswere shown in Fig. 6(a–c), respectively. The values of rate constants and calculated equilibriumadsorption capacity qe (cal) obtained for pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order models and experimental equilibrium adsorption capacity qe (exp) valueswere listed in Table 2. The values of kdif and Cwere calculated from intra-particle diffusion plot were summarized in Table 3. Although high correlation coefficient values were obtained for both
Please cite this article in press as: H.R. Mahmoud et al., Textile dye removal fro isotherm studies and thermodynamics, Advanced Powder Technology (2015),
pseudo first- order and pseudo-second-order kinetic models, the qe value from pseudo-first-order is more close to the experimental value than that calculated frompseudo-second-order kineticmodel. Therefore, it can be concluded that pseudo- first-order equation is better in describing the adsorption kinetics of Remazol Red RB-133 on different MgO nanomaterials.
Furthermore, we can observe that the rate constant values for pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order models increase as a following: MgOS > MgON > MgOU. It has been reported that the higher rate of dye adsorption by smaller particles was due to greater accessibility to pores and greater surface area for bulk adsorption per unit weight of the adsorbent, since have stated that the breaking up of larger particles to form smaller ones opens some tiny sealed channels that will be available for adsorption and therefore the rate of uptake by smaller particles was higher than that larger particle [51].
Fig. 6(c) shows the plot of qt versus t0.5 for Remazol Red RB-133 adsorption. The experiment data exhibit multi-linear plot, revealing that the process was governed by two steps. The first linear portion (phase I) can be attributed to the immediate utilization of the available sites on the sorbent surface. In contrast the phase II may be attributed to very slow diffusion of the sorbate from the surface site into the inner pores [46]. Thus the initial portion of Remazol Red RB-133 dye sorption by MgO nanomaterials may be governed by the initial intra-particle transport of the dye controlled by surface diffusion process and the later part controlled by pore diffusion. The values of kdif1 and kdif2 (diffusion rate constants for phases I and II, respectively) obtained from the slope of linear plots were listed in Table 2. Although the plot for the dye was linear, they do not pass through the origin. Therefore, it may be concluded that the boundary layer (film) diffusion was the rate controlling step in the process of dye adsorption in the present case.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Adsorption thermodynamics
sections.text:
The energy and entropy considerations were very important in order to understand the kinetics of adsorption. The effect of temperature on the sorption of 75 mg L 1 Remazol Red RB-133 on MgOS nanomaterial was studied by performing the adsorption experiments at different temperatures (293, 308 and 323 K). The results revealed that the sorption capacity decreased with increase in temperature from 293 to 323 K (Fig. 7a), indicating the exothermic nature of dye adsorption. The decrease in the rate of adsorption with the increase in temperature may be attributed to the tendency of dye molecules to escape from the solid phase to bulk phase [36].
The thermodynamic parameters of adsorption process such as change in standard free energy (DG ), enthalpy (DH ) and entropy (DS ) were calculated using the following van’t Hoff equation.
ln Kc ¼ DH =RT þ DS =R ð11Þ where
Kc ¼ qe=Ce ð12Þ
DG ¼ DH TDS ð13Þ
m aqueous solutions using cheap MgO nanomaterials: Adsorption kinetics, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2015.12.006
where Kc is the equilibrium constant, (qe/Ce) is the distribution coefficient, T is the temperature in Kelvin and R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J/mol K). Plotting lnKc against 1/T (Fig. 7b) gives a straight line with slope and intercept equal to DH /R and DS /R, respectively.
Table 3 gives the values of thermodynamic parameters obtained for the adsorption of Remazol Red RB-133 on MgOS nanomaterial. The negative values of DH indicate the exothermic nature of adsorption process for the dye. The negative value of entropy change (DS ) corresponds to a decrease in degree of freedom of the adsorbed species. This suggests the decrease in concentration of adsorbate in solid–solution interface, indicating there by an increase in adsorbate concentration on the solid phase. This is the normal effect of chemical adsorption phenomenon, which takes place through ion-exchange interactions [36]. In order to further confirm that chemisorption is the predominant mechanism, the values of activation energy (Ea) and sticking probability (S⁄) were calculated using a modified Arrhenius type equation related to surface coverage (h) as follows [52]:
S ¼ ð1 hÞe Ea=RT ð14Þ The S⁄ is a function of the adsorbate/adsorbent system under investigation, its value lies in the range 0 < S⁄<1 and is dependent on the temperature of the system. The value of h can be calculated from the following equation:
h ¼ 1 Ce=Co½ ð15Þ The Ea was calculated from the slope of the plot of ln (1 h) vs. 1/ T (Fig. 7c). The magnitude of activation energy gives an idea about the type of adsorption, which is mainly physical or chemical. The physisorption processes usually have energies in the range of 5– 40 kJ/mol, while higher activation energies (40–800 kJ/mol) suggest chemisorption [53]. The value of Ea for the adsorption of Remazol Red RB-133 on MgOS nanomaterial was found to be 624.6 kJ/ mol, suggesting that chemisorption was the predominant mechanism involved.
Gibbs free energy of adsorption (DG ) was calculated from the Eq. (13) and the values were given in Table 3. The negative values of DG indicated that the adsorption of the dye on MgOS nanomaterial is a spontaneous process, whereby no energy input from outside of the system is required. However, the values of DG decreased with increasing temperature, suggesting that of adsorption became less favorable at higher temperatures. As the temperature increases, the mobility of dye molecules increases, causing the molecules to escape from the solid phase to the liquid phase [54]. Therefore, the amount of dye that can be adsorbed will decrease. The increased mobility of dye molecules at elevated temperature may also be reflected in the values of Kc (Table 3). As the temperature increased, the values of Kc decreased, indicating lower affinity of the MgO nanomaterials towards the dye at higher temperatures [36].

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
It has been reported that the solution at a pH below the zero point charge (pHZPC) the surface of the sorbent is positively charged and can attract anions from the solution [55]. The charge of the Remazol Red RB-133 dye molecules is highly negative due to the presence of four SO3 groups on each molecule. So, the electrostatic forces of attraction between the positively charged MgO (pHZPC = 12.4) and negatively charged Remazol Red RB-133 is responsible for the high adsorption capacity observed.

The above results revealed that the adsorption capacity of MgOS nanomaterial was higher than the other adsorbents. This may be due to the strong adsorption affinity of MgOS toward the dye is probably due to its small particle size, highest surface area and pore volume coupled with electrostatic forces of attraction involved. Further it possesses more reactive surfaces due to the presence of high concentrations of edge/corner sites and other defects than the MgON and MgOU adsorbents.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
MgO nanomaterials were successfully synthesized by sol–gel and precipitation methods. The MgOS nanomaterial showed the highest removal efficiency of the Remazol Red RB-133 fromaqueous
Please cite this article in press as: H.R. Mahmoud et al., Textile dye removal fro isotherm studies and thermodynamics, Advanced Powder Technology (2015),
solutions. Langmuir isothermmodel was found suitable to describe adsorption. The dye adsorption followed pseudo- first-order kinetics. Evaluation of thermodynamic parameters revealed that the adsorption process is exothermic and spontaneous. The value of Ea for the adsorption of Remazol Red RB-133 on MgOS nanomaterial was found to be 624.6 kJ/mol, suggesting that chemisorption was the predominant mechanism involved. The adsorption characteristics of the MgO presented in this paper make this adsorbent a promising one in the field of adsorption for the removal of synthetic dye in wastewater treatment.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, three MgO nanomaterials (MgOS, MgON and MgOU) were synthesized by sol–gel and two different precipitation methods, respectively, and used for the sorption of Remazol Red RB-133 from aqueous solution. The effect of parameters like contact time, initial dye concentration and temperature on the adsorption capacity was studied. The adsorption isotherm studies were carried out using Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin models. Langmuir was the most suitable model to describe the adsorption isotherm. Pseudofirst -order model fitted well with good agreement with the experimental values of qe (equilibrium adsorption capacity). The complete removal efficiency of the dye on MgOS, MgON and MgOU adsorbents was attained when the contacting time was continued to 11, 40 and 60 min, respectively. Hence, the MgOS adsorbent was found to possess the highest removal efficiency of the dye from aqueous solutions. In addition, the thermodynamic parameters, DH , DS , DG , and Ea were also calculated for Remazol Red RB-133 adsorption onto MgOS adsorbent. In order to reveal the adsorptive characteristic of MgO nanomaterials, XRD, HR-TEM, FT-IR and N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out. The results showed that MgOS nanomaterial had potentially lowering capital and operational costs for practical applications. 2015 The Society of Powder Technology Japan.
